defined, remote connections for hosts so that tasks intended for
containers run as expected.

current working host's 'ansible_host', it's not looked up correctly

Heat is unable to execute the following join when creating the

subject: Defer radosgw key provision until OSD's detected
commit_message:
Defer radosgw key provision until OSD's detected

The RADOS gateway on startup will try to initialize a number
of pools in the Ceph cluster; if no OSD's are present at the
point of startup, this operation is re-tried for a period of
5 minutes.

As ceph-radosgw and ceph-mon are typically deployed in LXC
containers, they are up and running before ceph-osd units
are fully operational, resulting in ceph-radosgw units with
no running radosgw process.

By deferring the provision of keys to related ceph-radosgw
units until ceph-osd units are detected, the chance of this
race happening is greatly reduced.

Also add trailing space to ceph.conf as ceph requires that
configuration files end with a newline.

subject: Tighten the access rules for galera
commit_message:
Tighten the access rules for galera

Set a password for the 'root' db user and add an additional
'clustercheck' user to be used only by the resource agent.
The password for this 'clustercheck' user is randomly generated
via a heat parameter.

Before this change the workflow to set up the database in the
manifest is the following:
- Step 1 -> Install all the basic galera packages and basic configuration
- Step 2.a -> Create /etc/sysconfig/clustercheck with root and empty password
- Step 2.b -> Start up galera-monitor xinetd service
- Step 2.c -> Start pacemaker ocf resource (no root user has been created
  so there will be an empty password per default)
- Step 2.d -> Wait for /bin/clustercheck to return success and then
  proceed with the other steps

After this change the workflow is slightly more complex because there
is a bit of a chicken and egg problem:
- Step 1 -> Install all the basic galera packages and basic configuration
- Step 2.a -> Create /etc/sysconfig/clustercheck with root and empty
  password unless the file does exists already and has a clustercheck user
  configured
- Step 2.b -> Start up galera-monitor xinetd service
- Step 2.c -> Start pacemaker ocf resource (no root user has been created
  yet, so there will be an empty password per default)
- Step 2.d -> Wait for /bin/clustercheck to return success and then proceed
  with the other steps
- Step 2.e -> Create clustercheck db user
- Step 3/4 -> Create /etc/sysconfig/clustercheck with clustercheck user credentials
- Step 5.a -> Update the sql root password on the each node (at this
  stage
- Step 5.b -> Create /root/.my.cnf with proper credentials on all nodes

Note that we cannot really create the root/clustercheck users right at
step 1 because the db is not running yet (an approach that spawned
mysqld on each node, created the users and shut it down, was tried but
was much more complex and cannot work on updating existing setups)

Given the new way of solving the root password issue, we also need to
make sure that Step1 and Step2 are running on updates.

Closes-bug: #1581677

Depends-On: I83eed8885503043e881db34411616f9726e00352
Change-Id: If3d6e7253af6195b96129be7ea3348d697e4bae1

which is always use a timeout mode for blocking sockets.

subject: Fix listing of SLO manifest bytes after POST or COPY
commit_message:
Fix listing of SLO manifest bytes after POST or COPY

SLO middleware appends a swift_bytes param to the content-type of
manifests, expecting the container server to extract its value and
return it as the object size in container listings.

The SLO copy_hook is not copying swift_bytes from a source manifest
to a destination manifest during a regular COPY or a post-as-copy
request. This results in the wrong size appearing in the container
listing for a manifest that has been COPYed or POSTed to.

This patch modifies the copy-hook to copy across any swift_bytes
from the source response to the sink request. Since the swift_bytes
param is currently removed from content-type in the object controller
GET path, this patch also relocates the call to clean_content_type from
the object controller to the SLO GET handler. That means that swift_bytes
is available to the SLO copy_hook, but now it won't be cleaned up if SLO
is ever removed from the proxy pipeline.

There is very little test coverage for the handling of the
swift_bytes param. This patch adds a unit test for the container
server and some functional tests for the SLO scenarios.

Partial-Bug: #1260446

commit_message:
Reduce READ_FREQ and TIMEOUT for watch-file

The watch-file option currently relies on pyinotify which makes
use of select.poll. This is eventlet incompatible so it blocks
the whole thread for TIMEOUT milliseconds every READ_FREQ seconds.

This meant that an agent/service using this option is blocked for
500 milliseconds every 1 second.

Until a non-blocking alternative can be found, this adjusts the
READ_FREQ and TIMEOUT params on the FastWatchedFileHandler to
3 and 5 respectively. So every 3 seconds, it will block for 5
milliseconds so only 0.16% of time is lost instead of 50%.

subject: Cleanup orphaned DHCP resources on enable
commit_message:
Cleanup orphaned DHCP resources on enable

The current DHCP agent's implementation doesn't perform a complete
check for an existing device when setting up DHCP on a network.
In particular, if a subset of a network's DHCP resources are deleted
out-of-band (ex: namespace), the current check will pass resulting in
a new set of network DHCP resources being created, and the lingering
ones forgotten + orphaned.

Moreover, the existing interface drivers unplug() methods are not
idempotent and thus cannot be used to clean-up linering resources
for a said device; they only succeed when all DHCP resources exist.

This patch addresses the issue by introducing inherrited base logic
allowing lingering resources to be detected and cleaned up with
idempotence in mind. While the same result could be obtained by
adding logic to each driver, this approach reduces the code footprint
as well as duplication.

NB: I do realize this patch is a bit beefy. I'm more than happy to
refector into smaller patches assuming we can get some agreement
that this approach is acceptable.

Change-Id: Ib162510a8d781a027635000c471f42819201a16e
Closes-Bug: #1567049

subject: Add Image.create_from_func
commit_message:
Add Image.create_from_func

Image.cache() currently has different behaviour for 'generated' disks
and disks created from a glance image. This differing behaviour varies
from backend to backend. For example, it can be seen in the Lvm
backend, which does:

  generated = 'ephemeral_size' in kwargs

i.e. it requires this context but doesn't have it. It gets it by
grepping the arguments to the create function it was passed for an
ephemeral size, and infers the type based on that. The NoBacking
backend uses image_id instead, so it's not even consistent.

The interface is to pass a create function to Image.cache(), and
separately all of the arguments which will eventually be passed to it
if we need to call it.

This new interface makes it explicit to the backend that we are
creating a generated disk by having a separate method for doing this.
We also greatly simplify the calling interface by passing in a lambda
which takes a single argument: the destination path.

This patch also highlights a difference in caching behaviour between
backends: the Qcow2, Rdb, and Ploop backends currently cache function
output, whereas NoBacking and Lvm don't. This should eventually be made
consistent, but this patch explicitly aims to keep the current
behaviour.

Implements: blueprint libvirt-instance-storage

subject: Move files from mount points to actual file systems
commit_message:
Move files from mount points to actual file systems

The thing is that sometimes we have file system images and mount
point hierachies which are not aligned. Let's say, we have root
file system image, while partition scheme says that two file
systems should be created on the node: / and /var. In this case
root image has /var directory with a set of files. Obviously, we
need to move all these files from /var directory on the root
file system to /var file system because /var directory will be
used as mount point.
In order to achieve this we mount all existent file systems into
a flat set of temporary directories. We then try to find
specific paths which correspond to mount points and move all
files from these paths to corresponding file systems.

Co-Authored-By: Alexey Stupnikov <astupnikov@mirantis.com>

subject: Defer radosgw key provision until OSD's detected
commit_message:
Defer radosgw key provision until OSD's detected

The RADOS gateway on startup will try to initialize a number
of pools in the Ceph cluster; if no OSD's are present at the
point of startup, this operation is re-tried for a period of
5 minutes.

As ceph-radosgw and ceph-mon are typically deployed in LXC
containers, they are up and running before ceph-osd units
are fully operational, resulting in ceph-radosgw units with
no running radosgw process.

By deferring the provision of keys to related ceph-radosgw
units until ceph-osd units are detected, the chance of this
race happening is greatly reduced.

Also add trailing space to ceph.conf as ceph requires that
configuration files end with a newline.

Change-Id: I2a21f021502bde5c688bd3ac4b84ef24a8bdef68
Closes-Bug: 1577519
Closes-Bug: 1578403
